abstract.p: Ad Store, NY, opens .Comies, specializing in advertising and marketing for Internet companies, with offices in NY, Amsterdam and Paris; Paul Capelli, president of Ad Store, to add duties of chief executive of NY office of .Comies; Deepend, London, to open its first American offices in NY and San Francisco (Advertising column) (S)

block.p: Two agencies are expanding with a new operation and new offices.

Paul Cappelli, president of the Ad Store in New York, opened .Comies, specializing in advertising and marketing for Internet companies. .Comies begins with 25 employees at offices in Amsterdam, New York and Paris, handling accounts with billings estimated at more than $20 million from clients like Cityfeet.com, which helps small businesses find office and retail space.
Two agencies are expanding with a new operation and new offices.

Paul Cappelli, president of the Ad Store in New York, opened .Comies, specializing in advertising and marketing for Internet companies. .Comies begins with 25 employees at offices in Amsterdam, New York and Paris, handling accounts with billings estimated at more than $20 million from clients like Cityfeet.com, which helps small businesses find office and retail space.

Mr. Cappelli, 44, will add the duties of chief executive of the New York office of .Comies, and Charlie Herbstreith, 41, will be creative director; he had most recently been a freelancer. Laurent Forlani, 45, is chief executive in Paris; he had been president of the Paris office of the Ad Store. Alex van der Weide, 32, is chief executive in Amsterdam; he had been head account manager at Noordervliet & Winninghoff & Leo Burnett in Amsterdam, part of the Leo Burnett Company unit of the B Com3 Group.
And Deepend in London, a digital communications agency that is part of the Deepgroup Companies, is opening its first American offices, in New York and San Francisco.

At Deepend New York, with 12 employees and billings estimated at $2.5 million from clients like Kenneth Cole, Fred Brown, 29, will be managing director; he had been director at the Deepend London office. At Deepend San Francisco, with eight employees and billings estimated at $1 million from clients like Business 2.0 magazine, Paul Cloutier, 22, will be managing director.
